courseDescription: This course provides basic financial information an informed individual should understand in order to successfully reach their personal goals.  Topics include budgeting, goal setting, the process of accumulating and protecting wealth, use of credit, the car and housing decisions, and risk management.   Emphasis is on understanding how our behaviors affect successfully reaching these goals and how to improve decision making.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge on car and housing financial decisions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and improving personal financial behavior
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of personal financial goals and progress
Critical thinking in wealth accumulation and protection

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide students with basic knowledge of Wall Street while learning how to utilize Bloomberg Terminals to gain practical knowledge and experience. The Bloomberg Lab and Trading Room provides students with access to the comprehensive data system used by major national and international companies, financial organizations, and government agencies.  Students are required to complete Bloomberg Market Concepts program and earn a Bloomberg Certification, of value to many employers. Students will utilize an interactive trading game to experience the role of Wall Street traders and market makers.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Making market decisions in interactive trading game
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and utilizing comprehensive data systems

courseDescription: Financial analysis, planning, and control in the business enterprise. An introduction to budgeting, problems in long- and short-term financing, sources of capital and financial markets.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting financial data for non-financial stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Financial problem-solving for long- and short-term financing
Analytical thinking for financial planning and control

courseDescription: Introduction to the legal environment of business, providing the student with an understanding of the nature of public law and the regulation of business and of the basic principles that control business practices.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of basic principles controlling business practices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Application of law in business management

courseTitle: The Legal Environment of Electronic Commerce
courseDescription: This course will focus on the identification and management of legal issues and problems that confront businesses taking part in the rapidly growing internet economy.  Issues will include the establishment and protection of an online identity, electronic contracting, libel, product and firm disparagement, and unfair consumer practices.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identification of legal issues in e-commerce
Management of legal problems in online business
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and handling of unfair consumer practices
Problem-solving in product and firm disparagement
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading in the establishment of online identity

courseDescription: Student participation in a professional work experience.  Approval for enrollment and allowable credits is determined by the Finance department chair and the Career Development Services in the semester prior to enrollment. A transfer student must have completed one semester at Old Dominion University.
A special honors section of FIN 323.  Open only to students in the Honors Program in Business Administration.

This course is designed to provide students with a background in the field of estate planing. Topics will include wills and trusts, the probate system, estate and gift taxation, and fiduciary income taxation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with estate and gift taxation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex estate planning concepts in simple terms
Effective communication with clients about their estate planning needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing estate and gift taxation scenarios
Determining the most effective methods of estate planning based on individual client needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing estate planning information
Leading discussions about estate planning with clients

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide students majoring in personal financial planning with the ability to integrate technical material from previous coursework and prepare a comprehensive financial plan.  Emphasis will be on integrating knowledge, preparing a financial plan, and effectively communicating with a client.  Case studies will be emphasized.

This course develops the financial tools and knowledge needed to select among alternative financial assets.  The emphasis is on the individual investor.  Real world experience includes stock analysis, portfolio simulations and interactions with professionals in the securities industry.
Theoretical framework relevant to decision making in financial management; capital budgeting, capital structure, cost of capital, and working capital management.

An introduction to the understanding of futures and options.  Basic features and trading mechanisms; valuation of financial derivatives; methods of managing financial risk; arbitrage techniques; and speculation strategies.
An examination of the objectives, functions, policies, organizational practices, and government regulations of financial institutions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of organizational practices in financial institutions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding the needs of different stakeholders in financial institutions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in the context of financial regulations
Analyzing the impact of government regulations on financial institutions

courseDescription: Financial decision making involving flow and funds across national boundaries.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of international financial laws and regulations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Spotting potential financial risks in international context
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and implementing international financial strategies

courseDescription: Application of financial theory and techniques to the analysis and solution of actual financial problems.  Case analysis.
This course is designed to provide students with experience managing an investment fund.  The students will apply the theoretical knowledge of finance to manage a real portfolio.
For advanced students in financial management.
Risk theory as applied to the various fields of insurance, including life, health, property-liability and employee benefits.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of different insurance fields including life, health, property-liability and employee benefits

courseDescription: To develop an integrated approach to the methodologies necessary for the understanding of modern corporate finance.  Emphasis will be on integration of accounting and other internally generated information with external economic information within a framework for financial planning and valuation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of accounting and internal information
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating economic trends for financial planning
Critical assessment of business valuation methods
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating internal and external financial information

courseDescription: This course will provide students with an understanding of the theory and practice of investment decision making.  Students will learn to analyze risk and return characteristics of individual securities and portfolios and develop valuation models of various financial instruments.  Using insights from modern portfolio theory and equilibrium models of security prices, students will develop a framework for assessing the risk-return tradeoff.  The topics covered and tools developed in the course will be applicable for personal investment as well.

This course will introduce key principles of jurisprudence, dispute resolution, tort, constitutional, intellectual property and contract law.  Students will learn to create the ability to recognize when a matter poses a legal issue in the ordinary course of business and identify alternative solutions that the law will support and consider the ethical/moral implications of business decisions that the law does not yet address.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and communication of ethical/moral implications
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to identify alternative legal solutions
Analyzing ethical/moral implications of business decisions

courseTitle: The Legal Environment of Business and the Age of Electronic Commerce
courseDescription: An understanding of the traditional legal environment of business issues is essential for management to successively utilize e-commerce and respond to legal problems that it will present.  The course therefore examines dispute resolution, constitutional, tort, criminal, contract and property law, both in the context of traditional business practice and as applied to e-commerce.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of property law in the context of e-commerce
Understanding of contract law in e-commerce
Understanding of the legal problems presented by e-commerce
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Dispute resolution in business and e-commerce contexts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and responding to legal problems in e-commerce
Analyzing constitutional, tort, criminal, contract and property law in business contexts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Application of traditional business practices to e-commerce
Management of e-commerce in the face of legal issues

courseDescription: The course is a practicum in the field of finance, applying theories, concepts, and financial management tools in a business environment.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of financial theories and concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of financial theories to solve business problems

courseDescription: Study designed for students who have had one or more of the required courses waived, or for students desiring additional work in a finance area of particular interest.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of financial markets and instruments

courseDescription: Study designed for students who have had one or more of the required courses waived, or for students desiring additional work in a finance area of particular interest.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of real estate investments

courseDescription: Study designed for students who have had one or more of the required courses waived, or for students desiring additional work in an insurance area of particular interest.
A mathematical analysis of modern investment theory. Analyzes return and risk characteristics of individual securities and portfolios and develops valuation models of various financial instruments.

Examines such topics as the financial aspects of international business including financing and hedging activities of firms involved in international transfer of goods and services and decision making in connection with the asset management financing activities of multinational corporations.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in an international business context
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision-making in multinational corporations' financing activities
Analytical evaluation of international financial scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills in a multinational context

courseDescription: In no area of finance is the interface between academic theory and real-world practice as close as in the case of futures and options.  We have  now reached a stage where it is essential that all finance professionals understand how these markets work, how they can be used, and what determines prices in them.  This course addresses all these issues.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of academic theories to real-world finance scenarios
Determining prices in futures and options markets
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Keeping up with financial market changes

courseDescription: The course will comprise mainly cases but there will be some lecturing particularly on material not covered in FIN 605.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of financial concepts and policies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Oral and written communication for presentations

courseDescription: Designed to provide the advanced student with an opportunity to study independently or in small groups and investigate specific topics of current interest in the field of finance.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of financial software and tools
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of financial strategies and concepts

courseDescription: A mathematical analysis of modern investment theory. Analyzes return and risk characteristics of individual securities and portfolios and develops valuation models of various financial instruments.

Examines such topics as the financial aspects of international business including financing and hedging activities of firms involved in international transfer of goods and services and decision making in connection with the asset management financing activities of multinational corporations.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective decision making in a team
Communication of financial strategies and decisions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking in international business finance
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning and organization in multinational corporations

courseDescription: This course discusses the building blocks which much of financial theory is based on. In addition, a number of current topics in the literature are analyzed. Students are expected to read many of the original journal articles.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and analysis of financial topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing current topics in financial literature

courseDescription: The purpose of this course is to be acquainted with recent theoretical and empirical literature on investments, portfolio management and speculative instruments.  Emphasis will be placed on the development of methodological approaches to the various research problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding theoretical and empirical literature on investments
Application of methodological approaches in research

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide an in-depth understanding of the key issues of international financial management.  Topics covered include balance of payments, interest rates, international capital flows/markets and asset pricing, foreign exchange risk management, and international capital budgeting.

This course is structured to provide the student with research developments that lie on the frontier of corporate financial management.  Topics covered include optimal investment and financing decisions, cost of capital, option pricing theory, equilibrium valuation models, efficient capital markets, capital structure, dividend policy, mergers and acquisitions and international financial management.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of optimal investment and financing decisions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and leading financial research projects
Managing complex financial data and information

courseDescription: This course represents an advanced study of empirical research methods in finance. It focuses on the empirical techniques used most often in the analysis of financial markets and how they are applied to actual market data. Topics includes: statistical properties of asset returns, nonlinear dynamics, and volatility modeling of financial assets.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying empirical techniques to actual market data

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide an in-depth discussion of econometrics methods used to study financial markets with a focus on time series analysis.
Designed to provide the advanced student with an opportunity to study independently or in small groups and investigate specific topics of current interest in the field of finance.

An approved research project, written under the supervision of a faculty advisor, in which the student demonstrates the ability to conduct original research.  The complete project must be approved by the dissertation committee.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a research project under supervision

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.
